text:
# Top 10 Catchers of All Time

Based on the META drafts provided, here is a synthesized list of the greatest catchers in baseball history:

1. **Johnny Bench** (Cincinnati Reds)
   - 14-time All-Star, 2-time NL MVP (1970, 1972)
   - 10 Gold Glove Awards
   - 2 World Series Championships (1975, 1976)
   - Hall of Fame inductee (1989)
   - Career stats: .267/.342/.476, 389 HR

2. **Yogi Berra** (New York Yankees)
   - 18-time All-Star
   - 3-time AL MVP (1951, 1954, 1955)
   - 10 World Series Championships
   - Hall of Fame inductee (1972)
   - Career stats: .285/.348/.482, 358 HR

3. **Ivan Rodriguez** (Rangers, Tigers, Yankees, others)
   - 14-time All-Star
   - 13 Gold Glove Awards (most by a catcher)
   - 1999 AL MVP
   - World Series Champion (2003 with Marlins)
   - Hall of Fame inductee (2017)

4. **Mike Piazza** (Dodgers, Mets, others)
   - 12-time All-Star
   - 10-time Silver Slugger
   - Career .308 batting average with 427 HR
   - Hall of Fame inductee (2016)
   - Considered the greatest offensive catcher in MLB history

5. **Roy Campanella** (Brooklyn Dodgers)
   - 3-time NL MVP (1951, 1953, 1955)
   - 8-time All-Star
   - World Series Champion (1955)
   - Hall of Fame inductee (1969)
   - Career cut short by car accident

6. **Carlton Fisk** (Red Sox, White Sox)
   - 11-time All-Star
   - Gold Glove winner
   - Hall of Fame inductee (2000)
   - 24-year career (longest for a catcher)
   - 376 career home runs

7. **Bill Dickey** (New York Yankees)
   - 11-time All-Star
   - 8 World Series Championships
   - Hall of Fame inductee (1954)
   - .313 career batting average

8. **Josh Gibson** (Negro Leagues)
   - Hall of Fame inductee (1972)
   - Considered one of the greatest power hitters in baseball history

9. **Mickey Cochrane** (Athletics, Tigers)
   - 2-time MVP
   - Hall of Fame inductee

10. **Gary Carter** (Expos, Mets, others)
    - 11-time All-Star
    - 3-time Gold Glove winner
    - World Series Champion (1986 with Mets)
    - Hall of Fame inductee

Note: There was consistency across META drafts regarding the top positions (especially Johnny Bench and Yogi Berra). Some variations existed in the ordering and inclusion of certain catchers, particularly for positions 7-10. Josh Gibson's specific statistics were omitted due to inconsistency in the META drafts.
